subject: Re: should new Integer(1) equal new Long(1)
msgSnippet: Hello, I think David was saying B *should* fail, but is passing at the moment. But I agree with vaughnbutt that we shouldn t be fixing java.lang in junit.

Hello,

I think David was saying B *should* fail, but is passing at the mom=
ent.

But I agree with vaughnbutt that we shouldn't be fixing java.lang in
=
junit.

Maybe some junit addon could help this by having assertValueEqual()=
 or
some sort...

My 2 cents...

Timothy Wonil Lee
--- In junit@yahoogroups=
.com, "vaughnbutt" <vaughnbutt@...> wrote:
>
> I'm glad B will fail as it s=
hould.
> 
> To me, the principle least surprise means that when o1 and o2 a=
re not
> null (regardless of their type) then
> 
> assertEquals(o1, o2)
> 
=
> should have the same result as
> 
> assertTrue(o1.equals(o2))
> 
> If tha=
t means that A fails then so be it.
> 
> Having said that, I am a bit surpr=
ised that Integer.equals only
> "likes" other Integers (and not Longs for e=
xample).  But we shouldn't
> be fixing java.lang in junit.
> 
> --- In juni=
t@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@> wrote:
> >
> > All,
> > 
> > Kent a=
nd I continue to try to fine-tune equality to produce the least
> > surpris=
e, and continue to wonder if well enough should have been left
> > alone.  =
In 4.3, we introduced some run-time math magic to make up for
> > the lack =
of type-expansion once we had removed most of the primitive
> > type assert=
Equals methods.  Thus, it became the case, somewhat
> > accidentally, that =
this would pass:
> > 
> > assertEquals(new Integer(1), new Long(1));  // A
=
> > 
> > However, it simultaneously became the case that this would also pa=
ss:
> > 
> > assertEquals(new BigDecimal("1.0"), new BigDecimal("1.1"));  /=
/ B
> > 
> > Line B should certainly fail.  The simplest thing to do is to =
remove
> > our math magic, introduce assertEquals(long, long), etc, and let=

> > numerical classes define their own equality.  This means that line A
>=
 > will now fail, since that's how Integer.equals() is defined.  This is
> =
> a small behavior change, but a "regression" of sorts.
> > 
> > If anyone =
believes this is a damaging decision, please let me know.
> > 
> >    David=
 Saff
> >
>
